advanced_ddos.description: Cloudflare will stand in front of your website regardless of attack size or duration.
advanced_ddos.help:
#### What is a DDoS attack?
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack uses a cluster of computers to send a large number of requests to a website all at once effectively overloading the website with traffic and taking it offline. To learn more see [here](https://www.cloudflare.com/ddos).
advanced_ddos.title: Advanced DDoS Protection

bic.description: Evaluate HTTP headers from your visitors browser for threats. If a threat is found a block page will be delivered.
bic.help:
#### What is Browser Integrity Check?
Browser Integrity Check looks for requests with HTTP headers commonly used by spammers, bots, and crawlers such as requests with a missing or non-standard user agent. If a threat is found, Cloudflare will present a [block page](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/360029779472#error1010).

**Note:** Browser Integrity Check may affect some actions on your domain. For example, it may block access to your API. You can selectively enable or disable this feature for any part of your domain using Configuration Rules.
bic.title: Browser Integrity Check

bots.card.help:
**What does this feature do?**

 If you have enabled Bot Fight Mode, Cloudflare may issue computationally expensive challenges in response to some requests. These challenges may discourage bot operators from accessing your site.

**Does this feature use JavaScript?**

Yes, Bot Fight Mode may use lightweight JavaScript to detect bots. This process is asynchronous, invisible to the client, and CSP-compliant. No personally-identifiable information is gathered. Cloudflare will fingerprint the client device (determining browser type, GPU, and more) to improve the efficacy of Bot Fight Mode. [Learn more about JavaScript detections](https://developers.cloudflare.com/bots/reference/javascript-detections).

**What else should I know?**

 Bot Fight Mode may challenge/block API or mobile application traffic.

bot_management.help_contents:
If you have Bot Management enabled, Cloudflare will allow the deployment of firewall rules for bot mitigation purposes to your zone. You may disable or remove any of these firewall rules from your zone at any time by going to the firewall tab of your Cloudflare account.

Firewall rules applied to your zone count towards your total allotment of firewall rules. You may see audit log events when firewall rules for bot mitigation are deployed to your zone.

bot_javascript_detections.title: JavaScript Detections
bot_javascript_detections.description: Use lightweight, invisible JavaScript detections to improve Bot Management. [Learn more about JavaScript Detections](https://developers.cloudflare.com/bots/reference/javascript-detections/).
bot_javascript_detections.description_no: Use lightweight, invisible JavaScript detections to improve Bot Management products.
bot_javascript_detections.help:
#### What does this feature do?
If you have enabled JavaScript Detections, Cloudflare will inject a small amount of invisible code into client devices. This code is run asynchronously and does not collect personally-identifiable information. Cloudflare will fingerprint the client device (determining browser type, GPU, and more) to determine whether or not the client is making automated requests. This improves the efficacy of Bot Management and Bot Fight Mode.

 #### What traffic is affected?
JavaScript is only injected in response to requests for HTML pages or page views, excluding AJAX calls. API & mobile traffic is unaffected. Once code is injected, it is not injected again until its 30-minute session life expires.

#### What else should I know?
If you have a Content Security Policy (CSP), you may need to update it. For more details on CSPs and JavaScript Detections, [view our support article](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/360045224651).
bot_javascript_detections.confirm_disabl: Disabling JavaScript Detections can reduce the accuracy of bot detections.
Disabling JavaScript Detections while using WAF rules with a JavaScript detection field will result in failed challenges and blocked user.

challenge_ttl.help:
#### Why doesn't the TTL apply to the WAF?
Challenge passage does not apply to challenges issued by the WAF (Web Application Firewall) as these challenges are not based on the visitor's IP address reputation.

filter_based_firewall.help:
Firewall rules offer power and flexibility by targeting HTTP traffic and applying custom criteria to block, challenge, log, or allow certain requests.

In essence, firewall rules allow you to examine incoming site traffic. Requests matching the criteria you defined are subject to a specific action in response.

* **Log** - Records matching requests in the Cloudflare Logs.

* **Bypass** - Allows user to dynamically disable Cloudflare security features for a request.
 NOTE: Requests which match the Bypass action are still subject to evaluation (and thus a challenge or block) within firewall rules, based on the order of execution.

* **Allow** - Matching requests are exempt from challenge and block actions triggered by other firewall rules content.
 NOTE: The scope of the Allow action is limited to firewall rules; matching requests are not exempt from action by other Cloudflare Firewall products, such as IP Access Rules, WAF, etc.

* **Challenge (Interactive)** - The client that made the request must pass an interactive Challenge.

* **JS Challenge** - The client that made the request must pass a Cloudflare Javascript Challenge before proceeding.

* **Block** - Matching requests are denied access to the site.

For more details about Actions, see https://developers.cloudflare.com/firewall/cf-firewall-rules/actions/

To learn more, visit:

* [Get started with firewall rules](https://developers.cloudflare.com/firewall/cf-firewall-rules/)
* [Manage rules via the APIs](https://developers.cloudflare.com/firewall/api/)
* [Troubleshooting](https://developers.cloudflare.com/firewall/troubleshooting/)

filter_based_firewall.priority.confirmat:
Use **Priority** when your ruleset exceeds 200. Priorities evaluate from lowest to highest number. For example, a priority of 10 evaluates before priority 11.

The default action-based evaluation sequence (**Log**, **Allow**, **Managed Challenge**, **JS Challenge**, **Interactive Challenge**, and **Block**) goes into effect when:

- A rule has no priority.
- Two or more rules have the same priority.

If you have 200 or fewer rules, you can use the **Order** option to drag and drop.
Use priority numbers to control rule precedence?

firewall.access_rules.help:
#### What option should I choose?

- **Block:** Ensures that an IP address will never be allowed to access your website
- **Interactive Challenge:** Specified IP addresses will be shown a challenge to solve before being allowed to access your website
- **JavaScript Challenge**: The JavaScript challenge page requires the visitor to wait 5 seconds while Cloudflare determines if the visitor is coming from a real browser. The challenge requires the visitor's browser to answer a math problem which takes a bit of time to compute. Once successfully answered, the browser will be remembered and won't be challenged again.
- **Allow:** Ensures that an IP address will never be blocked from accessing your website. The IP may still be mitigated if part of a DDoS attack. Only use for verified IPs that you trust!

**What can IP Access Rules be applied to?**
IP Access Rules can be applied based on:

- **IP address**
- **IP address range:** Cloudflare accepts the following CIDR notations: /16 and /24 for IPv4 addresses and /64, /48, and /32 for IPv6
- **Autonomous System Number (ASN):** An ASN is the unique identifier for any network, such as the Cloudflare network (AS13335). The accepted format for ASN's is "AS12345"
- **Country:** Specified using ISO 2-letter country codes, such as "US" for the United States

You can apply IP Access Rules to this domain only or all domains in your account.

To modify an existing Access Rule, create a new Access Rule and delete the existing one.

firewall.events.help:
#### Firewall Events
For a better understanding of how our Firewall events work along with how our WAF correlates with these events, please check out our detailed article [here](https://developers.cloudflare.com/waf/analytics/security-events/).

Each entry contains:

- **Rule type**
- **Action taken**
- **Source IP of the web request**
- **Country associated with the source of the web request**
- **Hostname of your server which has been accessed**
- **Time**

The **details** link provides additional information about a specific request.

You can search Firewall events based on:

- **Ray ID:** A specific identifier of a request going through Cloudflare's network
- **Source IP Address**
- **Rule ID of a Firewall Rule**
- **Group ID:** Contains several firewall rules.

 Click [here](https://developers.cloudflare.com/waf/analytics/security-events/paid-plans/) for additional information on searching in your Firewall events

#### What does the Cloudflare package contain?
These rules are written and curated by our in-house engineers; they are also updated whenever a new vulnerability comes out to automatically protect you from it. We [recommend using the default settings](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200172016).

firewall.package.owasp.help:
#### How does OWASP work?
The OWASP rules operate in scoring threshold mode: each match against a rule increases the threat score of that request. Once a request exceeds a [configurable sensitivity threshold (low, or high)](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200172016), an [action is taken](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200172016). All OWASP blocks appear in your logs as caused by [Rule ID 981176](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200172016#sJbboLurEVhipzWYJQnyz).

Individual rule groups within the OWASP package can be enabled or disabled in "rule details", after which rules can be [managed at the individual rule level through the advanced option](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/200172016).

firewall.tab.dos_card.description: Cloudflare's automated DDoS protection systems constantly analyze traffic and generate real-time signatures to mitigate attacks across the network and application layers. These mitigations are automatically enabled for all customers across all plans.
firewall.tab.dos_card.help:
**What is a Distributed Denial of Service attack?**
A [Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ddos/what-is-a-ddos-attack/) is a malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server, service or network by overwhelming the target or its surrounding infrastructure with a flood of Internet traffic.

**How does Cloudflare protect me against a DDoS attack?**
Cloudflare's [autonomous DDoS protection systems](https://blog.cloudflare.com/deep-dive-cloudflare-autonomous-edge-ddos-protection/) use a set of dynamic rules that scan for attack patterns, known attack tools, suspicious patterns, protocol violations, requests causing large amounts of origin errors, excessive traffic hitting the origin/cache, and additional attack vectors. Each rule has a predefined sensitivity level and default action that varies based on the ruleu2019s confidence that the traffic is indeed part of an attack.

**Available actions**
* **Block** - Matching requests are denied access to the site.
* **Challenge (Interactive)** - The client that made the request must pass an interactive Challenge.
* **Log** - Records matching requests in the Cloudflare Logs.
* **Use rule defaults** - Uses the default action that is pre-defined for each rule.

**Available sensitivity levels**
* High (default)
* Medium
* Low
* Esentially off

**Notes:**

* **Essentially Off** means that weu2019ve set an exceptionally low sensitivity level so in most cases traffic won't be mitigated for you. However, attack traffic will be mitigated at exceptional levels to ensure the safety and stability of the Cloudflare network.
* **Log** means that requests won't be mitigated but only logged and shown in the dashboard. However, attack traffic will be mitigated at exceptional levels to ensure the safety and stability of the Cloudflare network.  

**Additional resources**

* [Overview of Cloudflare DDoS Protection](https://developers.cloudflare.com/ddos-protection/)
* [About Cloudflare DDoS Protection](https://developers.cloudflare.com/ddos-protection/about/)
* [Announcement blog](https://blog.cloudflare.com/http-ddos-managed-rules/)
* [How to handle false positives or false negatives](https://developers.cloudflare.com/ddos-protection/managed-rulesets/adjust-rules/)
* [Simulating test DDoS attacks](https://developers.cloudflare.com/ddos-protection/reference/simulate-ddos-attack/)
* [API documentation](https://developers.cloudflare.com/ddos-protection/managed-rulesets/http/configure-api/)
* [Learning Center](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/ddos/what-is-a-ddos-attack/)
firewall.tab.dos_card.ddos_protection.de:
Ruleset managed by Cloudflare that automatically mitigates HTTP-based DDoS attacks such as HTTP floods, amplification HTTP attacks, and reflection HTTP attacks.

HTTP DDoS attack protection is always enabled. To customize the ruleset behavior, create a DDoS override.

firewall.tab.dos_card.network_layer_prot: Network-layer and SSL/TLS DDoS attack protection

Rulesets managed by Cloudflare that automatically mitigate SSL/TLS-based and Network-layer DDoS attacks such as SYN floods and UDP reflection attacks.

Network-layer DDoS attack protection protects all Cloudflare customers, but only Magic Transit and Spectrum customers on an Enterprise plan can customize the managed ruleset.
Customers also using Magic Transit and Spectrum can customize the Network-layer DDoS Managed Ruleset from Home > Network Security > DDoS.
Initiates DDoS protection automatically once your origin server responds to Cloudflare with an increased rate of errors 52Xs.

* Zero-day vulnerabilities * Top-10 attack techniques * Use of stolen/leaked credentials * Extraction of sensitive data

Search for traffic logged by the enabled managed rulesets. Based on your assessment of the logged traffic, you can then adjust the actions for managed rulesets to your desired setting.

The APIs for managing the previous version of WAF managed rules will stop working on 2025-06-15. The same applies to Terraform resources related to the previous version of WAF managed rules. You must migrate before this date to avoid any issues.

Save newly learned API schema to improve API security

Cloudflare has learned an API schema that you can apply to protect your API endpoints. API schemas define which API requests are valid based on several request properties like target endpoint, path or query variable format, and HTTP method. Applying a learned schema or uploading your own allows Cloudflare to creates rules for incoming traffic based on the schema definitions. These rules define which traffic is allowed and which traffic gets logged or blocked.

security_analytics.ai_assistant.intro:
**AI Assistant for Security Analytics** helps you craft custom filters using natural language. Enter queries into the input below to create and compare data series. **AI Assistant** only operates on filters u2014 it currently has no ability to analyse your data for top or most frequent occurrences.

For more information, see the [announcement post here](https://blog.cloudflare.com/security-analytics-ai-assistant).

settings.manage_detections.description: Manage the Security detection tools available for %{zoneName}. Set the required configurations to enable them and optimize your security posture.
security_rules.description: Perform security actions on incoming requests that match specified filters. Rules are evaluated and executed in order, from first to last.
security_rules.title: Security Rules
security_rules.rules.custom.title: Custom rules
security_rules.rules.custom.tooltip: Control incoming traffic by filtering requests according to rules you define.
security_rules.rules.custom.form.descrip: Protect your website and API from malicious traffic with custom rules. Configure mitigation criteria and actions, orxA0explore templates, for better security.
security_rules.rules.rate_limit.title: Rate limiting rules
security_rules.rules.rate_limit.tooltip: Define rate limits for requests matching an expression, and the action to perform when those rate limits are reached.
security_rules.rules.rate_limit.form.des: Protect your website and API from malicious traffic with rate limiting rules. Configure mitigation criteria and actions for better security.
security_rules.rules.managed.title: Managed rules
security_rules.rules.managed.tooltip: Pre-configured rulesets maintained by Cloudflare. To skip the execution of managed rulesets or some of their rules, create an exception rule.
security_rules.rules.managed.form.descri:
Managed rules protect your application by analyzing characteristics from each request and determining how the request should be completed.
A managed rules exception skips execution of other rules. You can skip all remaining rules or specific rules from a Managed Ruleset.
security_rules.rules.sequence.title: API sequence rules
security_rules.rules.sequence.tooltip: Define rules for API requests based on the order they occur.
security_rules.rules.sequence.form.descr:
Allow, block, or log API requests if they hit your API endpoints in a certain order (sequence).
A sequence is defined by a starting and final API endpoint. For a request to be considered as matching this rule, the starting endpoint must be one of the last 9 endpoints the request hits before hitting the final endpoint.
security_rules.rules.jwt.title: API JWT validation rules
security_rules.rules.jwt.tooltip: Define rules for API requests based on their attached JSON Web Tokens.
security_rules.rules.jwt.form.descriptio: Use Cloudflare's edge network to check for JSON Web Tokens on incoming requests.
security_rules.rules.client_side.title: Client side rules
security_rules.rules.client_side.tooltip: Define what resources (such as scripts) are allowed on your applications through [Content Security Policy (CSP)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy) directives.
security_rules.rules.client_side.form.de: Define the web resources (such as scripts) allowed on your applications through [Content Security Policy (CSP)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy)  directives. Client-side rules can enforce an allowlist, effectively blocking resources not included in the rule, and can also log violations when incoming requests attempt to load a resource not allowed by the rule
security_rules.rules.ip_access.title: IP access rules
security_rules.rules.ip_access.tooltip: Allow, block, or challenge traffic based on the visitor's IP address, country, or Autonomous System Number (ASN).
security_rules.rules.ip_access.descripti: IP Access Rules can be based on IP address, IP address range, Autonomous System Number (ASN) or country.
security_rules.rules.ip_access.form.desc: Allow, block, or challenge traffic based on the visitor's IP address, country, or Autonomous System Number (ASN).
security_rules.rules.zone_lockdown.title: Zone lockdown rules
security_rules.rules.zone_lockdown.toolt: Lockdown a URL on your zone to only allow specified IP addresses.
Zone lockdown a specific URL on your zone to specific IP addresses. This is useful to protect an admin or protected area from non-specified IP addresses.
security_rules.rules.user_agent.title: User agent rules
security_rules.rules.user_agent.tooltip: Block specific browser or web application [User-Agent request headers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/User-Agent).
security_rules.rules.user_agent.form.des: Take action on a request based on what browser or application made the request. User agent rules work by checking the [User-Agent request headers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/User-Agent) included in a request. These rules apply to the entire domain instead of individual subdomains
security_rules.rules.ddos.network.title: Network-layer and SSL/TLS DDoS attack protection
security_rules.rules.ddos.network.descri: Rulesets managed by Cloudflare that automatically mitigates SSL/TLS-based and Network-layer DDoS attacks. Only Magic Transit and Spectrum customers on an Enterprise plan can create overrides for these rulesets.

security_rules.rules.ddos.form.descripti: Ruleset managed by Cloudflare that automatically mitigates HTTP-based DDoS attacks. HTTP DDoS attack protection is always enabled. To customize the ruleset behavior, create a DDoS override.

user_agent_rules.card.help:
User-Agent Blocking allows you to block a specific (complete) User-Agent string, and provides you with options as to how block/mitigate it. The list of actions permitted are the same as the IP Firewall, those being Block, JS Challenge, and Managed Challenge.

This is best used in a scenario where you are under attack from a specific User-Agent, or looking to block specific versions of a browser or web application, e.g. "curl/7.37.0"

waf_switch.confirmation.title: Confirm
waf_switch.confirmation.description: Are you sure you want to disable the Web Application Firewall?
waf_switch.description: Provides enhanced security through a built-in ruleset to stop a wide range of application attacks.
waf_switch.help:
#### What are managed rules?

A [Managed rule](https://developers.cloudflare.com/waf/reference/legacy/old-waf-managed-rules/) blocks requests that contain malicious content. Our managed rules are [state-of-the-art](https://www.cloudflare.com/waf) and provides strong security without impacting performance.
**Note:** Turning off managed rules will disable all packages including OWASP, Cloudflare Rules, and any custom rules youu2019ve set. We donu2019t recommend doing that. If you encounter issues caused by managed rules, this guide explains how to [diagnose and fix them by tuning your WAF configuration](https://developers.cloudflare.com/waf/reference/legacy/old-waf-managed-rules/troubleshooting/).

#### How do managed rules protect my website?

Our managed rules [uses rulesets to block common attacks](https://developers.cloudflare.com/waf/reference/legacy/old-waf-managed-rules/) like cross-site scripting (XSS) and SQL injections. Furthermore, we patch and update our Cloudflare Package Rulesets constantly, so that when a new vulnerability is exposed, you will be protected from it just by having our managed rules enabled. The rest will be done by our engineers.

zone_lockdown_card.description: Lockdown a specific URL on your zone to specific IP addresses. This is useful to protect an admin or protected area from non-specified IP addresses.
zone_lockdown_card.help:
Zone Lockdown allows you to allow specific IP addresses and IP ranges whereby all other IPs are effectively blocked. This is best used to protect an Administrative area of a website to, e.g. an office or VPN.

Zone Lockdown supports:
Specific sub-domains, allowing you to, for example, allow IP 1.2.3.4 to access domain foo.example.com and allow IP 5.6.7.8 to access domain bar.example.com, but not necessarily allow the vice versa.
Specific URLs, allowing you to, for example, allow IP 1.2.3.4 to access directory example.com/foo/* and allow IP 5.6.7.8 to access directory example.com/bar/*, but not necessarily allow the vice versa.
This is useful when you need more granularity in your IP Access Rules since, with the IP Firewall, you can only either apply the block to all sub-domains of the current domain, or all domains on your account, and you can not specify URIs.

Advanced Options:
In a scenario where you have multiple Zone Lockdown rules, which overlap, you can set a priority to ensure one Zone Lockdown rule is honored over another. For example, if you protected example.com/admin/* but also had example.com/admin/api/* - and the users to API had a different set of IP allowed IP addresses, then this would keep this area protected.

The *lower* the number, the *higher* the priority. Higher priority rules take precedence over those with lower priority.
